p: The P&S was dosed with 200 mL of septic tank effluent (STE) every 12 h over 1.5 h, corresponding to 400 mL d -1 (22.6 L m -2 d -1). The SND and GEO received wastewater that had passed through a single-pass sand filter (SFE). They were dosed with 22.5 mL SFE every 30 min over 15 min, corresponding to 2000 mL d -1 (113 L m -2 d -1). Dosing rates were based on regulations governing OWTS design in the state of Rhode Island [ 21, 22]. Septic tank effluent and SFE were collected weekly from the same treatment train at a residence in South Kingstown, RI, USA. Permission was provided by the homeowners to access and sample their septic system for the duration of this study. Wastewater was stored in sealed plastic containers at 4°C in the dark after collection before dispensing small volumes to chilled plastic holding containers maintained at 4–16°C for dosing. The characteristics of wastewater inputs ( Table 1) are within the range observed by others [ 23– 25].
